div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,546] ALEXANDRIA, MONDAY, JULY 16, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for Express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin and London, leaving Brindisi at 7 a.m. Arrival Venice every Wednesday about 8:30 a.m. in time for Express to Switzerland, Paris and London leaving Venice 2 p.m. and 11:20 p.m. . Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 3 p.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Triente-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4:50 p.m. Passengers from Cairo will find special through carriages and luggage-van attached every Saturday to Express leaving Cairo 9:30 a.m. and are conveyed directly to Quay alongside steamer.

div.p: CAIRO-KHARTOUM SUMMER MAIL SERVICE.
Commencing from 1st of April, 1906, until further notice.

Sleeping and Dining Cars.–- During the month of April Sleeping and Dining Cars trains leave Cairo for Luxor on Wednesday, Mondays and Saturdays at 6:30 p.m., and Luxor for Cairo on Sundays, Tuesdays and Thursdays at 6.30 p.m.

From 1st of May 1906, these trains will be suppressed, byt Dining and Sleeping Cars will be attached to the ordinary night Trains from Cairo and Luxor three times a week, on the same above mentioned days.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: The Engish Daily Newspaper, Established 1886
Editor and Manager - - R. SMELLING
ONE PLASTRE TARIFF
Monday, July 16, 1906.
THE FINCAIAL SITUATION.

The deep-tooted distrust with which thinking men of all classes have been brought to regard the finance of the London County Council will not be lessened by the recent debate in the House of Lords. It has been the usual custom to treat the Bill, by which that body receives annually its borrowing powers, as a private measure, and to allow it to pass undebated through all its stages. This year it occurred to Lord Camperdown that a Bill which placed £19,000,000 at the disposal of the councillors in Spring gardens deserved at least some words of explanation from Lord Welby, the chairman of the Finance Committee. The London County Council is very remarkably situated in all matters regarding expenditure : it is under the supervision if no department of Government, and though its annual estimates are required to be “considered and approved” by its Finance Committee, this requirement is habitually disregarded. Warnings and remonstrances by the eminent specialists who serve on the committee are laughed at and set aside whenever they point to economy, land the presence of men like the late Lord Lin-geo, like Lord Welby, like Sir Francis Mowatt, at the Council board has ceased to be any guarantee of the reasonableness or security of the Connoil’s undertakings. Last year an ex-chairman of the Council declared, with doe sense of his responsibility, that its commitments were appalling, and that he looked upon the future with the gravest apprehensions. Even since then matters have gone from bad to worse. The costly failure of the river steamboat service is no longer a matter of dispute; the enormous expenditure on tramways is booming rapidly jeopardize! by the development of the motor omnibus; the Electric Supply Bill threatens an immeasurable vista of extravagance in the near future; the Council is about to embark upon the erection of a costly Hotel de Ville, which is ostentation dy intended as a rival for the Houses of Parliament; its finance is still juggled in a way which renders it almost hopeless to distinguish between loss and gain; and the cost of its building operations is still systematically and grossly under-estimated.

The spokesmen of the Council in the Upper House scarcely attempted to deny these allegations ; nor could they refuse to admit that be credit of the richest city in the world has sunk in the money market below that of Birmingham and Manchester. All that Lord Monkswell could do was to point to the fact that the ratepayers had steadily maintained the dominant faction in power. Unfortunately, it is too true. The criminal apathy of the Unionist voter has saddled the London ratepayer with the Old Man of the Sea, from which it seems that he can never shake himself loose. And neither age nor responsibility have taught moderation or wisdom to the Radicals and Socialists at Spring-gardens: the leading members have strengthened their position by obtaining seats in Parliament, and the purses of the Londoner who has got anything to be robbed of are literally at the mercy of a band of brigands. But, apart from the sufferings of individuals, this matter of municipal extravagance, of which London offers the most flagrant example, is fast becoming an Imperial question of the first magnitude. The piling op of local loans, the reckless handling of local finance, is rapidly affecting the national credit. The diminishing power of expenditure among the rank and file of the population is combining with a well-grounded fear as. to the security of many of the undertakings upon which their capital has been adventured. However much the export and import returns may be cited, there has never been in our modern history such an otter stagnation and depression in all public securities. The “City, * to use a conventional term, has never gone through such times since the Baring crisis in 1891, and men of the largest experience and the highest reputation in we financial world are weighed down with the gloomiest anticipations. On the one hand, they see the municipal bodies throughout the kingdom refusing absolutely to cat their coat according to their cloth, or to take any notice of the diminished financial capacity of the country. On the other hand, they have a Government in power-which seems utterly callous at . to the delicate condition of affairs both in oar own colonies and among the great Powers of the world. With the exception of Sir Edward Grey, there is not a Minister who can open his mouth without increasing the general unrest. ( Globe’.)

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: A native of 24 was tun over by a train near Mallaha on Saturday, and succumbed to bis injuries on the spot.
The Ministry of Public Works has decided to erect three slaughterhouses in Foukh, Kafr el Sheikh, and Quesna markazes respectively.
H.l.M. the Sultan has issued has issued an irade ordering the creation of a number of special houses, a hospital, and a pharmacy at Mecca, to be set aside for the use of poor pilgrims.
A fire broke out on Saturday in a tailor's shop near Shadir el Battikh, but was extinguished by the brigade in less than an hour. The damages have not yet been estimated.
The Government has suppressed the last issue of the native weekly paper "A1 Papa-galle El Misri,” which contained some mischievous cartoons and statements relative to the Denishwai case.

We should like to call the attention of our readers to the case of two distressed French ladies previously mentioned in our columns. Any contributions on their behalf will be thankfully received by the editor.

Hassan Zagzoug, the native onbashi who accompanied the five British officers at Denishwai, is still alive, contrary to the rumors of his sudden death. Hassan was arrested on the 11th inst., and will be brought to-day before a council of discipline at Shibin el Kom for trial.

We understand that the Government will shortly submit to the Mixed Court of Appeal a draft decree relative to the adulteration of butter and similar substances. By the provisions of this decree the sale of butter mixed with other fatty substances is not prohibited provided that the vendor does not sell the compound as butter or in a shop where butter is exposed tor sale.

The committee of the London Stock Exchange have fixed July 18 as a special settling day in Cairo Syndicate, Limited—9,500 shares of £1 each fully paid, Nos. 1 to 7 and 5,008 to 14,500; and have ordered the undermentioned security to be quoted in the official list: Land and Mortgage Company of Egypt, Limited—£103,400 Four per Cent. Debenture Stock.

In view of the extension of secondary education in Egypt, the Ministry is on the look-out for applicants for a number of professorships —two in science, six in mathematics, and several in history and geography - which will be filled this autumn. Candidates are required to possess a University degree in honours, experience in teaching, and, if possible, an educational diploma. We understand that Mr H.T. Boyd-Carpenter, Senior Inspector to the Ministry of Education, will be charged with the task of making a section from the applicants.

A Cairo contemporary states that on the night of Wednesday last the driver of the Upper Egypt night express, while traveling between Tahta and Meshta, suddenly caught sight of a number of heavy boulders lying on the line. He immediately applied the brakes and succeeded in stopping the train in time to prevent a disaster. The shock caused by the sadden stopping of the train caused a panic among the passengers, and a number of them attempted to proceed on foot to Meshta, which was not far distant. The train staff, however, succeeded in removing the boulders and the train proceeded on its journey, arriving in Cairo three quarters of an hour late.

The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be consulted by members requiring clerical or other assistance. Applications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Address, Secretary, British Chamber of Commeroe, Alexandria. [Advt.]

div.head: TURKISH MUTINY.
div.p: FIVE BATTALIONS REBEL.
General Shot.
LONDON, Monday, July 16.

Five battalions of Turkish reservists have mutinied at Hodeida. Over 300 were killed or wounded in attempting to suppress the mutiny. A Turkish general has been condemned by a court-martial and shot for provoking the revolt.
The “Times” has received the following from the Imperial Ottoman Embassy :—

"A telegram from Aden, published by some London papers on the 2nd inst., stated that 16 battalions of Turkish reserves mutinied in Yemen and set out for Sana, demanding to be sent home; that the commander-in-chief ordered the forts to open fire on the mutineers, who surrendered after hundreds of them had been killed; that a certain rebellious Imam’s forces were advancing, and that a battle was reported with heavy losses on both Bides.
"The Imperial Ottoman Embassy is authorized to declare that there is no foundation whatever for any of the above statements.”

After giving several reasons for believing that there is no religious fanaticism in Egypt, “Al-Ziher” writes : What fate is in store for us ? That is the question over which the public are now brooding. Some people seem to be of the opinion that the Anglo French Agreement bas given “new” colour to the Egyptian question, and made many 0atomans and Egyptians imagine that England is getting a firmer hold in Egypt, and that this fact will lead to the conclusion of an agreement between Turkey and Great Britain, whereby the former Power might assent to the administration of Egypt by the latter ; preserving for herself the sacred right of suzerainty over this country, which should continue to pay her the usual tribute, as is the case in Cyprus under the control of England; and that Egypt will, at last, be in a position to obtain an administrative independence. But we are of another opinion. Egypt, which lies — as an isthmus—between Constantinople and Mecca, enables the power that gets a firm hold of it to spread its influence not only over Africa but also over Asia. The Ottoman Government is aware that the Mohamedan world sympathises with it not only because it is a Moslem Government, but because of the religious prestige of the Caliph and guardian of the Imamate, the defender of the two holy shrines of Mecca, the two Kiblahs. Turkey is aware that the European governments have surrendered themselves to a policy of unlimited ambition : so that if one foreign power possesses Egypt, the neighboring countries— Syria, El Irak, Yemen and the Hedjtz will be exposed to great danger. Therefore, it will be impossible for Turkey to agree to surrender the administration of Egypt to England. Good judges are of opinion that England will not create a serious change in the general policy of the world on account of Egypt. It will be not benefit her to declare a protectorate over Egypt. Such a declaration will, on the one hand, show that the British Government haB broken its promises, and perhaps set forces in motion that may lead to unpleasant results, and, on the other hand, will produce no new benefit to England. The imaginary protectorate can never add influence and strength to the absolute authority which the English practice nowadays in Egypt, but will cost them dearly in trouble and expense. Consequently, neither England nor Turkey nor Egypt can benefit by the alteration of the present state of the latter country ; and it we consider that a state will never lead an absolutely monotonous and unchanging existence ad infinitum, that the temporary occupation of Egypt will lead to no danger to Turkey, and that no agreement concluded between governments can be regarded as permanent, and that, after all, the general ignorance now prevailing in the Orient will Borne day vanish and be replaced by enlightenment—if we consider all these Lets', we mast perforce conclude that the day will come when Egypt will be released from its political restraints and restored to Turkey, its first controller ; and when England will oblige the Egyptians by withdrawing the occupation from this country.

Mr. Jay, Secretary of the United States Legation at Constantinople, last week presented to Tewfik Pasha, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, a Note announcing that President Roosevelt and Congress had decided to raise the Legation to the status of an Embassy, and that as soon as Mr. Leisbman received his credentials as Ambassador he would cease to fill the office of Minister of the United States, The Note concludes by expressing the hope that the decision of the American Government will be regarded as a new proof of the friendly relations existing between the two countries and of the esteem of the United States for Turkey.

div.head: FANATICISM IN EGYPT.

p.hi: FRENCH VIEWS OF SIR E. GREY'S STATEMENT.

div.p: The statement made in the House of Commons by Sir Edward Grey on native unrest in Egypt has aroused great interest in France, and sympathy with England is generally felt in the most influential circles, as difficulties with which Britain has to contend in this country are fully understood and appreciated. As the “Standard’s” Paris correspondent aptly remarks, time was when Frenchmen might have been inclined to rejoice in England's difficulties, to be sarcastic over the result of twenty odd years of British administration ; bat those days have gone by, and, besides, it ie well, though not generally, known that France in the north-western portion of the African continent ia face to face with the same mysteriously moving danger. The movement which is taming the peaceful, laborious fellaheen into fanaticaripe for mischief is not confined to Egypt; it is not merely racial in origin.it is a religious upheaval felt all across Northern Africa, and likely to be more violent among the warlike tribes of the French Sudan than among the unmartial peasants of the Nile.

“I have (the correspondent adds) heard many strange tales about its inception and its development, and particularly about the secret support given to it by a Christian Power. I do not wish to pass .for a mischief maker between England and Germany, bat at the risk of so doing I must say that it is the latter power against whom the accusation is brought of fostering a Pan-Islamic movement As indisputable evidence, the action of her diplomacy at Constantinople, her intrigues in Syria and Asia Minor, and especially the interference of the Emperor in person in favour of the Sultan of Morocco are mentioned. But it is further stated that her agents in Morocco, in Algeria, in Tripoli and in Egypt are so directly implicated that they are actually engaged in helping the spread of an anti-Christian agitation. An official in the German Legation at Cairo is especially mentioned as beiDg a particularly active occult director of the movement.

“Whether these latter statements be true or not I cannot say, but I have heard them from men whose word is not to be taken lightly. It is certain, however, that Germany has encouraged Turkey against the Powers, and has emboldened Morocco to flaunt France; by so doing, she has encouraged, if not kindled, a spirit of resistance in the Mohamedan mind to all Christian authority.
The French press, too, supports the firm attitude adopted by England in the matter of the Pan-Islamic movement.

The “Figaro” says :—The cause which the British are defending in Egypt, whether in the interior or on the Turkish frontier, is the cause of civilization. This cause is the more particularly ours, inasmuch as we have so many Mussulman subjects. The telegrams say Sir E. Grey’s tone was grave. Events have proved, and will prove, that he does not exaggerate the seriousness of the situation. It is not by chance that Turkey has violated the Persian and Egyptian frontiers, and it is certainly not by chance that other incidents are occurring elsewhere. The visit of the Emperor William and the protection accorded by Germany to the Sultan of Morocco have everywhere awakened Mussulman fanaticism, encouraged Pan Islamism and inspired barbarians with fresh hopes against civilization. Every country most take measures, as Great Britain has done in Egypt, to prevent the spread of the movement, and each must be on its guard.

M. Dombasle declares in the “Siecle” that to show pity for the Egyptian assassins would lead adversaries of the British domination to believe they had the sympathies of politicians in London—an illusion that would be dangerous.

The Paris correspondent of the “Pall Mall Gazette” writes:—An eloquent silence has fallen upon the Press in respect of Egypt, with one or two exceptions. No one speaks of it. It is not difficult to imagine what the comments would have been like a few years ago. Now there are two influences to restrain—one the Entente, the other a fellow-feeling engendered by the problem in Morocco. The Arab, especially of the nomadic tribes, is a very different man from the fellaheen who under normal conditions has very little fighting staff in him.

Moreover, students of British Colonial methods know that revolt has very little chance of success whilst a man of the calibre of Lord Cromer is at the head of affairs in Egypt, and the general direction of foreign policy in the hands of Sir Edward Grey. The Press is generally responsive to the higher political necessities of the Quai d’Orsay. Now, it is against the interests of the moment to stir no international strife; the Legislature, concerned with placating advanced and Socialist opinion, is directly opposed.

Egypt is a hornet’s nest for this reason : that, in examining the situation there you are almost bound to come to certain definite conclusions of a disquieting nature. The revolt of the fellaheen is but a symptom of a general sickness that has spread across the whole of Northern Africa. The first outward manifestation was Algeciras. Briefly, the “agent provocateur” is abroad, and revolt, whether amongst the Arabs or the Egyptians, is to be traced to a certain Power, whose conversations at Constantinople have borne their expected fruit That, at least, is the view taken by serious observers here.

div.head: FRENCH NATIONAL FETE.
div.p: H.E. Mustapha Pasha Ibadi, Governor of Alexandria, exchanged official visits on Saturday with M. Pierre Girard, who held a reception at the French Consulate. Patriotic speeches and toasts were received with remarkable enthusiasm, and the health of M. Failures was drunk amid acclamations.
At 8 p.m. the official banquet took place at the New Khedivial Hotel, M. Girard presiding. The leading members of the French colony were present at a very animated and successful function.
Numerous French commercial establishments were brilliantly illuminated on Saturday evening, among them the Credit Lyonnais, the French Club, the Comptoir National d'Escompte, etc.

The Casino at San Stefano was crowded on Saturday night, and the whole of the interior of the Casino building brilliantly decorated with the flags of all nations and brightly illuminated. The Greek Philharmonic Society’s band played with remarkable vigour during dinner, and on its temporary departure the Bracale orchestra appeared, and a vocal and instrumental concert followed. In spite of the inevitable noises that proceeded from the crowded Casino, the songs were audible and much appreciated.

The concert over, the public streamed out on to the terrace and the cinematograph began to flicker. Oar French friends will excuse us if we say that the series of views to which we were treated suggested a Bonapartist demonstration. To begin with, we saw the "Little Corporal,” or someone sufficiently like him, reviewing his grenadiers near the Pyramids. Then came a ball under the Directory, in the midst of which the Greek musicians, who had reoccupied the baed-stand, attacked the “Marseillaise” with stunning vehemence. Scenes from Austerlitz send the Russian campaign, with the famous episode of the sleeping sentry, followed, and the death of the Emperor and emblematical tableaux representing the pest—all fire and sword—and the future depicted under the guise of a floral iete.
Then game the fireworks, and when at 11.30 p.m. blue, green, and red Catherine wheels revolved vigorously to the strains of the “Mattchiche,” the fete had reached its height.

At Cairo all the Diplomatic Agencies and Consulates flew their flags in honour of the anniversary and the tricolour was everywhere in evidence in the streets. At 10 a.m. M. Nettement held a reception at the French Consulate, which was followed by a similar function at the French Diplomatic Agency, where M. de Valdrome did the honours.
In the evening a gala performance at the Zaitoun and Rod-el-Cafe CM chantants and ietes at the Kasr-el-Nil terrace and at the Ambassadors were largely attended till the small hours of the morning.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
Suez, Sunday.
Yesterday morning, at 10 o’clock, a reception was held at the French Consulate, which was attended by the members of the French colony.

In the afternoon, at Terre Plein, opposite the club, in a well decorated enclosure, a gymkhana took place. The programme principally consisted of childrens,’ ladies,’ and gents’ potato-races, and also of several other sports, for which prizes were distributed to the winners.
In the evening dancing commenced at 9.30 in the club room, which was largely attended. The ball was kept up to a late hour, when the Suez guests returned by special train.
After this date watering is permitted subject to the existing programme for rotations, which will remain in force until notice is given to the contrary.

The Fairfield Shipbuilding and Engineering Company, Limited, have received an order from the Egyptian Mail Steamship Company, Limited, for the construction of two very large mail and passenger steamers to be driven by turbine machinery. These vessels will he of the very highest class and of great speed.

div.head: ALECANDRIA SPORTING CLUB
div.p: JULY SKYE MEETING

Saturday’s Skye Meeting was a very agreeable function. The weather was of the pleasantest, and there was a fairly large gathering of the public in the enclosure. There were seven races on the card, and the greatest interest was taken in all. Most of the look was with Khalil Pasha Khsyat, who won four of the seven events, Ibrahim Bey Cherif winning two others. Betting was fairly animated and the prices realised in several cases were quite tempting, especially in the July Plate, in which Kordofan rewarded his backers by a 31 to 1 chance. The band of the R. Dublin Fusiliers played a choice selection of music during the afternoon, which was greatly appreciated. The following are the details of the various events:

NOVICES RACE of P.T. 1,560, viz: P.T. 1,250 to winner and P.T. 250 to 2nd horse. For Arabs that have never ran in a race of any description, Amateur races and Gymkhanas excepted. Weight for age. Distance 3/4 mile.

Coming out of the catting he was leading the field by 8 lengths and, never being challenged, won in the easiest fashion by a couple of lengths, half-a-length separating second and third. Time: 1.25.
Totalisator paid P.T. 89 on winner and P.T. 23, 20, and 22 for places.

Time : 1.24.
Totalisator paid P.T. 37 on winner.

JULY PLATE of P.T. 2,500, viz : P.T, 9,000 to the winner and P.T. 500 to 2nd horse. For Arabs that have not won a race of the net value of P.T. 5.000 since the 1st April 1906. Weight for age with penalties. Distance round the course.
Ibrahim Bey Cherifs g.a.h. Kordofan, 8.11. Eliseo. 1
Messrs. A. J. Sursock and Michael ides’ g.a.h. Jupiter, 9.7. Challoner. 2
Ishak Bey Hussein’s b.a.h. Moofid,9.7.Bonser.3
Khalil Pasha Ehayat’s g.a.p. Sadik, 10.0. Thompson. 4
Mr. E Bustros’ b a.h. Don Quiohotte II, 9.9. Fenwick. 0
Ibrahim Bey Cherifs b.a.h. Merawi, 9.7. Burnham. 0
Ibrahim Bey Cherifs g.a.p. Zeibeok, 9.5. Parsods. 0
Saleh Bey Yaghen’s g.a.b.g. Mizzaud, 9.4. Claridge. 0
Mr. E. Karam’s g.a.h. Hector, 9.7. Hassan Suliman. 0

Sadik jumped off and made the running, followed by Jupiter and Mizziud, till the mile post was reached. This order was maintained as far as the f.mile post, when Jupiter forced his way to the front followed by Kordofan, with Moofid lying up. Turning into the straight, Jupiter and Moofid were well abreast with Mizzaud in attendance. Near the polo houses, Mizzaud, Jupiter, and Moofid were racing neck and neck, when Kordofan came with a wet sail and stole off Jupiter, winning cleverly by 11/2 length. A length divided 2nd and 3rd. Time : 2.32.
Totalisator paid P.T. 636 on winner and P.T. 97,49, and 31 for plaoes.

TROPICAL PLATE of P.T. 2,500, viz : P.T. 2,000 to the winner and P.T. 800 to 2nd horse. For Arab ponies that have not won a race of the net value of P.T. 5,000 since the 1st April 1906. Weight for age and inches with penalties. Distance round the course. Khalil Pasha Khayat’s ch.a.p. Suleik, 9.7. Thompson. 1
Saleh Bey Yaghen’s b.a.p. Bulkeley, 9.3. Claridge. 2
Ibrahim Bey Cherif’sg.a.p. Atbara, 8.4. Eliseo. 3
Saleh Bey Yaghen’s b.a.p. Abou Arkoub, 9.7. Aly Selim. 4
Ibrahim Bey Cherif’s c.a.p. Ateche, 9.7. Parsons. 0
Mr. E. Karam’s gap. Jubilee, 8.13. Hassan Suliman. 0

All got off to a good start except Bulkeley, who was slightly left Suleik made the running, followed by Ateche, Bulkeley, Abou Arkoub, and Atbara, to the mile post, when Ateche and Atbara dropped back, with Suleik still leading. The latter led out of the outing and although Bulkeley tried to come to terms with him he could never overtake him, and Suleik won by a couple of lengths, a similar distance separating 2nd and 3rd. Time : 9.32.
Totalisator paid 33 on winner and P.T. 20, 36, and 31 for places.
PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
Mr. A. L. Webb, C.M.G., left Cairo for Assouan on Saturday, and after inspecting the reservoir and dam will return to Alexandria, where he will stay for a few days.
Mr. W. P. Graham, of the Public Health Department, is at present at Alexandria on a visit of inspection.

We regret to announce tha sudden death of M. E. Massai, manager of our Cairo confrens “I’Imparziale,” which ocoured on Saturday afternoon at Alexandria. While waiting for a tram in the company of Mme Arus, the wife of M. Arus, proprietor of the "Imparziale,” who had invited M. Massai to spend a few days with him at Ramleh, and another lady, M. Massai dropped down dead. Apoplexy is believed to have been the cause of death.

Colonel Francis W. Trevor, M.B., who has been appointed Surgeon General on the retirement of Surgeon-General W.H. MeNamara, C.B., took part in the Gordon Relief Expedition in 1884. For his services be received a medal with clasp and the Khedive’s decoration. During the last South African operations Burgeon-General Trevor officiated as principal medical officer to a division, and saw most of the important fighting in the Transvaal, Orange River Colony, and on the Zululand border, and his work there gained him mention in despatches and the Queen’s Medal with five clasps.
